Package io.github.derivasians.calculatte

Class CalculatteEnvironment

java.lang.Object
io.github.derivasians.calculatte.CalculatteEnvironment
public class CalculatteEnvironment extends Object
Contains all instance variables required for Calculatte to run. These mainly consist of values used for rounding and other accuracy controls within calculations.
Version:
1.0 Snapshot
Author:
Matthew Okashita

  • Field Details

    • FACTORIAL_ROUNDING_DECIMAL_PLACES

      public static int FACTORIAL_ROUNDING_DECIMAL_PLACES
      Represents how many decimal places this variable's respective calculation(s) should be rounded too. Only values returned by a method are rounded. Intermediate values within a method are never rounded, unless by another method; e.g., the revolve() method's calculations get rounded when the integral is taken with integrate() and once more when the final value is returned.

      Note: Setting any of these values to -1 will prevent that group of calculations from being rounded. This can be useful if you would prefer to use your own rounding method or none at all.

    • INTEGRATION_ROUNDING_DECIMAL_PLACES

      public static int INTEGRATION_ROUNDING_DECIMAL_PLACES
      Represents how many decimal places this variable's respective calculation(s) should be rounded too. Only values returned by a method are rounded. Intermediate values within a method are never rounded, unless by another method; e.g., the revolve() method's calculations get rounded when the integral is taken with integrate() and once more when the final value is returned.

      Note: Setting any of these values to -1 will prevent that group of calculations from being rounded. This can be useful if you would prefer to use your own rounding method or none at all.

    • DERIVATION_ROUNDING_DECIMAL_PLACES

      public static int DERIVATION_ROUNDING_DECIMAL_PLACES

    • LIMIT_ROUNDING_DECIMAL_PLACES

      public static int LIMIT_ROUNDING_DECIMAL_PLACES
      Represents how many decimal places this variable's respective calculation(s) should be rounded too. Only values returned by a method are rounded.       Note: Setting any of these values to -1 will prevent that group of calculations from being rounded. This can be useful if you would prefer to use your own rounding method or none at all.

    • POSITIVE_INFINITY

      public static double POSITIVE_INFINITY
      All values greater than CalculatteEnvironment.POSITIVE_INFINITY will be rounded up to Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY by Calculatte.round().

      Note: Setting CalculatteEnvironment.POSITIVE_INFINITY to Double.MAX_VALUE will prevent rounding values up to Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY.

      See Also:
      Calculatte.round(double, int)

    • NEGATIVE_INFINITY

      public static double NEGATIVE_INFINITY
      All values less than to CalculatteEnvironment.NEGATIVE_INFINITY will be rounded down to Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY by Calculatte.round().

      Note: Setting CalculatteEnvironment.NEGATIVE_INFINITY to Double.MIN_VALUE will prevent rounding values down to Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY.

      See Also:
      Calculatte.round(double, int)

    • N

      public static int N
      Accuracy value for integration calculations. The larger the more accurate.
      See Also:
      Calculatte.integrate(double, double, Function)

    • H

      public static double H
      Accuracy value for derivation calculations. The smaller the more accurate.
      See Also:
      Calculatte.derivate(double, Function)

    • DERIVATIVE_TOLERANCE

      public static double DERIVATIVE_TOLERANCE
      Largest difference between the left and right derivative before the derivative does not exist.
      See Also:
      Calculatte.derivate(double, Function)

    • DERIVATIVE_OFFSET

      public static double DERIVATIVE_OFFSET
      How far the x-value should be offset left and right to find the left and right derivatives.
      See Also:
      Calculatte.leftDerivative(double, Function), Calculatte.rightDerivative(double, Function)

    • LIMIT_TOLERANCE

      public static double LIMIT_TOLERANCE
      Largest difference between the left and right limit before the limit does not exist.
      See Also:
      Calculatte.limit(double, Function)

    • LIMIT_OFFSET

      public static double LIMIT_OFFSET
      How far the x-value should be offset left and right to find the left and right limits.
      See Also:
      Calculatte.leftLimit(double, Function), Calculatte.rightLimit(double, Function)

    • SQUARE

      public static final int SQUARE
      These static constants define what known cross section is being used to calculate a volume of cross section.
      See Also:
      Calculatte.crossSection(double, double, Function, Function, int), Constant Field Values
